Comment: You mean she's not accommodating the ravenous feeding frenzy of the beltway press desperate to have something to talk about less than a year after the last general election. I really get offended when these people that regularly attend the WHPCD pretend that their own daily Game-of-Thrones dramas are what the actual populace is dwelling on. I'm also annoyed at any implication that its unreasonable to be silent on a 2028 run in 2025. Any insinuation that normal people are waiting on tenterhooks for any one individual and biting their nails is pure projection.  Cool your fucking JETS on future elections, 'journalists'! Something has to actually happen for you to "journal" it, right? Otherwise you're just waxing poetic about possible futures.  I've got an idea -- the current president is up to quite a bit. Did you notice? Go cover some of it! I guarantee you that AOC is more worried about that right now, herself. Nobody owes you an "announcement" three years out, so I give you permission to peel your eyes off of that concern for a few seconds.

Comment: Sadly, that's about four years from now.  It's 2028, meaning she wouldn't be able to run for President *or* Governor.  And I kinda think her best move might be to go for Governor.  I mean, that's me wish-casting because I'd like a Governor candidate I'd be willing to vote for (and Hochul ain't it - never again with her crypto-Republican ass), but it'd also give her some executive experience to round out her resume so that when she does run for President, nobody can say she isn't "qualified."  Waiting until 2028 just to maybe become a junior Senator who'd then need to spend time in the Senate to fulfil that obligation is pointless.  Honestly if she isn't gonna run for Governor, I'd rather her just run for President in 2028 straight-away.

Comment: Yes, I am aware of David Hogg's plan to primary Democratic office-holders.  But, to me, what is needed is for him to recruit some of the powers that be in the party to exert a much harder shove than he can render on his own.  I thought a lot of the blame for the Democrats trying to hide Biden's condition and sneak him into a second term belonged to the big names in the party.  Obama and the two Clintons, in addition to others, should have been pressuring him hard, not only not to run, but to step down. The same is true now.  That group needs to shove Schumer and others, for instance my own very good former rep and now Senator, Ron Wyden, to step aside and let the next generations have their chance.  I say this as a 76-year-old myself.
